title: Study Advice
description: Listen to students discussing effective study methods.

audio.text:
Kate: Hi James, you look stressed. What's wrong?
James: I have three exams next week and I don't know how I'm going to prepare for all of them.
Kate: That sounds tough. Have you made a study plan?
James: Not really. I usually just study everything the night before.
Kate: That's probably not the best strategy. If you try to learn everything in one night, you won't remember much.
James: I know, but I always leave things to the last minute.
Kate: Maybe you should try a different approach. If you study a little bit every day, the information will stick better.
James: How do you organize your studying?
Kate: I make a schedule. I divide each subject into smaller topics and assign specific days to each one.
James: That sounds very organized. What if you don't understand something?
Kate: If I get stuck on something, I usually watch YouTube tutorials or ask a classmate. There are great resources online.
James: Do you think online resources are as good as textbooks?
Kate: They can be. If you find the right channels, they explain things really well. But you should also read your notes and textbooks.
James: What about memorizing facts? I find that really difficult.
Kate: If you use flashcards or apps like Anki, it becomes easier. They use a system where you review things just before you forget them.
James: I've heard of that. Spaced repetition, right?
Kate: Exactly! And here's another tip: if you study in a quiet place without your phone, you'll concentrate much better.
James: That's my biggest problem. I get distracted by my phone constantly.
Kate: Turn it off or leave it in another room. If you check your phone every few minutes, you'll lose focus.
James: You're right. I'll try your advice. Thanks, Kate!
Kate: No problem. Good luck with your exams!
